content:
Method 1

Right-click the message > Save As > HTML Files > Save.

Right-click the saved HTML file > Open With > Word

There is, unfortunately, no option in Thunderbird to do the above on the fly.

Method 2

Right-click the message > Edit as New Message

Edit as needed

File menu > Save As > File.

When done, simply close the editor. If a copy of the edited message is automatically saved in the Drafts folder, just delete it from there and you're done.

content:
Thanks for your kind reply :-)

Ok, maybe the link above is misleading ...

Here a new attempt to make it clear what I would like to achieve:

One use case is: You receive regularly email with attachment, you have four options:

  • keep them as is (that transform your email-box into a file storage, this might be inconvenient)
  • forward the email to yourself, save the attachment in an appropriate directory, add a note where the attachment is stored, afterwards delete the original email (bad workaround)
  • modify the email (save the attachment outside of your email-box, add information about the file location)

In outlook you have two options to achieve the third option:

  • install an add-on or code something in VBA
  • edit the email and save the modified email (without attachment but with the information included about the file location of the original attachment)

Another use case might be, you would like to just correct something in an email, e.g. an internet-link that is outdated

Now I wonder how this can be achieved in Thunderbird, the option "edit as new" is not suitable for my purpose.
creator: stefan169

content: So, you want to keep the modified email in your mailbox, minus the attachment (stored externally), and delete the original email to reduce your email server storage quota usage?
creator: stancestans

content: After modification of this email there is no need to remove, it is just the opposite, the objective is, to keep the modified email in your email-box. You want to keep the full content, the attachment is still available (but outside of the email-box) and also the email itself.
creator: stefan169

content:
So, directly edit the message in-place. Well, the only thing that comes close is this add-on https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-GB/thunderbird/addon/header-tools-improved/

If the intention is to keep the message in the mailbox, with full content including the attachment, then why bother to edit it in the first place? So, you're editing this message to include storage location information for where its attachments were saved locally, but the edited message itself still contains this attachment. It just doesn't make any sense.

No, the objective is to safe the space in the email-box, the attachment is afterwards stored outside the email-box in a separate folder, the modified email might afterwards look similar to this:

content: In a previous question, you stated the affected account is an IMAP account. If that is the case, right-click the account and select Subscribe. The dialog that opens should show all your IMAP mailbox folders, including the Deleted folder. Simply make sure to place a tick next to the folder to subscribe to it. Quit and restart Thunderbird, and the Deleted folder should be in the Folder Pane as before.
creator: stancestans

content: Thank you for your prompt reponse. I have followed your directions; the deleted items folder now appears on the left hand folder listing...now without a dustbin symbol as before, but after deleting items since your directions, none have appeared in the folder. Please advise Thanks and regards Peter J.
creator: faldocourt

content: Right-click your account on the left hand folder listing (Folder Pane) once again and select Settings. The Account Settings page will open with your account in focus (selected). On the left pane, click on Server Settings. On the right pane, go to the line that says "When I delete a message" then select the option that says "Move it to this folder". Right next to that option, there is a drop-down list of all the IMAP folders that you've subscribed to, including the Deleted folder. Select that Deleted folder then close the Account Settings tab. Restart Thunderbird.

content:
I'm not having the problem with threaded view auto enabled, I just get a list of any emails which were in the thread, so unthreaded list. But the one I selected to see is not highlighted so basically I have no idea which one I selected. All the From is the same and so is all the subject, so like you I have to recheck the date and sometimes time as well of the one I selected. It's just a painful process which did not occur in 102.15.1

Either way - I would expect:

  1. Unthreaded list
  2. Email I clicked on to be highlighted
  3. Email I clicked on to auto open and display contents below.

I've just created a bug on this issue.

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1860815


Do you have the auto threaded view switched off ? I have done the following and do not have a problem in the search results window. See if it helps you.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom
  • click on 'Config Editor' button - It opens in a new tab
  • In search type: default_view
  • You will see this line: mailnews.default_view_flags - It will have a numerical value of 1
  • click on the 'pencil' icon on the right to allow an edit.
  • Remove the number 1 and type in a zero 0
  • click on the 'tick' icon to save your settings.

You will now have: mailnews.default_view_flags - It will have a numerical value of 0 This will now mean any new folders you create, they will not have threading by default.

See if setting this preference helps to stop the threading in search result.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I've made that change and hopefully it may help in the future, but the behavior with existing folders and the search behavior is unchanged. Hopefully the bug report will result in it getting fixed. Thanks

content: I found the solution. If you click on the name of one of your email accounts in the left hand panel, at the top you will see two clouds - one at the top of your screen and one slightly below it. Click on the lower one and it will only download emails from the account you have clicked on.
creator: Helvetica

content:
Nice to see you come back and share what you learned ... Thank you

If you also want to NOT have an account fetch emails when you start Thunderbird and NOT fetch emails every n minutes (default set to n = every 10 minutes), then go to (v 115 menus used) Edit -> Accounts Settings -> Server Settings

Scroll down to "Server Settings"

You will see three checkboxes which are checked by default and to change the behaviour of that account UnCheck the actions you do NOT want to happen 

_ Check for new messages at startup _ Check for new messages every [ n ] minutes _ Automatically download new messages

Note that if your email provider "Pushes" emails to you, like some providers do with IMAP accounts, these settings may be ignored. You could rty using POP connections if that is the case.

creator: paul.cassel

content:
I was saying simply rename the file. Mozbackups are zip files. So anything ZIP can help. A lot!

While there have been many changes, the fundamentals of mbox files have not changed in 20years. So you can import the mail stored in MBOX files(the only option until a few years ago). Regardless of how it was backed up using the impoprtexporttools. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

Note that in your backup you will have mbox files with no file extension paired with an MSF file, but only if mozbackup was a complete backup. It had lots of minor backups that contained basically nothing.

The address book likewise have changed to a SQLite database files, but the old format MORK is imported by the default import of address books from a file.

There are other ways without the tools to get your old profile, but it is easier for most folks to use a menu driven system as telling them to copy file around just looses them at the first step. Just as I lost you.

content:
Did you originaly mean to ask a question about how to go back to an earlier version ? Because I'm not sure what your question is supposed to be about!

You paid someone to uninstall new and reinstall old.

In future if anyone finds this question and does not want to pay to downgrade then try this:

In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Under 'Application Basics' half way - Profile Folder - click on 'Open Folder' (if Windows OS) or 'Open Finder' (if a MAC)

A new window opens showing the contents of your 'profile name folder'

Exit Thunderbird now

delete this file: 'compatibility.ini'

Uninstall Thunderbird


Get a fresh download from this link: Last version before update to 115* was 102.15.1 http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/102.15.1/

If windows select eg: 'win64/' if MAC select 'mac/' then choose prefered language eg: en-GB is English British Then download the .exe file if Windows OS or the .dmg file if MAC Install and run and it will pick up your profile.

creator: Ansamb

content:
Ano, trochu logické vysvětlení to je, ale je to velmi nepraktické a velmi to rozhází komunikaci.

Ano, u jedné odpovědi to lze tolerovat, ale u komunikace skládající se z cca 6 ~ 10 odpovědí, to je pak... Přitom zachování vlákna komunikace je důležitá, neb se jednoduše dohledá vše potřebné zmíněné v komunikaci.

Poměrně často komunikuji se zákazníky a mnoho věcí upřesňujeme, čímž je komunikace velmi dlouhá. Pokud se do každé odpovědi přidá vertikální oddělovací čára, tak předchozí odpověď bude mít dvě čáry, před-předchozí pak tři čáry atd. (a to nezohledňuji, že by vertikální čáry přidával i klient zákazníka, čímž by se počet čar zdvojnásobil), a tak postupem času z originálních textů jsou nepřehledné paskvily.

Přitom originální text je oddělen jednoduchými řádky obsahující odesílatele a datum doručení atd. Není tedy zapotřebí zavádět další oddělovač.

V každém případě děkuji za odpověď. Nic není dokonalé a tak budu hledat cesty, jak se s tímto vypořádat.

content:
Idadho said
I've been told that the development team does not really care.

Then you are sadly misinformed - you might want to more carefully vet your information source. If the team did not care, they would not have someone specializing in accessibility, a focus which hasn't existed in the history of the product.

This is not mean that no mistakes are possible, or that everything that is demanded gets adopted. But it does mean that we are making great progress in accessibility, and that the team does care.
creator: wsmwk

content:
I've seen comments from those people who are supposed to be focused on accessibility. They don't give a rat's behind about what is truly needed. I will gladly stand before any of them and tell them how they have failed to make very simple changes that will improve accessibility.

Those in the accessibility team appear to be quota fillers so they can make the claim,"Yes, we have an accessibility team" Microsoft and Apple are the same. They serve the vision impaired/blind and a few other disabilities at a minimal level and consider the job done.

I used to do product testing for Intuit and TurboTax. I know how changes CAN be made. Quicken Home and Business was a result of the user team I was on.

Text under icon option. At the very least, a description when you pause your cursor over an icon. Every function should be obviously understandable. Nothing should require learning then memorizing how to do a task. Proper contrast. 4.6 to 1 is the required minimum contrast. Minimize clutter or make it optional. Those stupid yellow diamonds come to mind. The circled numbers next to folders, too.

There are untold millions of people who have difficulty with shades/contrast.

Firefox and T'Bird use to be eons ahead of Chrome and Edge for usability/accessibility. They have been backing into the useless swamp that Chrome and Edge have ruled for years.

I am likely the most intelligent person they will ever meet who has a visual processing disability. Most people who struggle with tech turn inward and just resign themselves to say "I'm just too stupid to use this." They are not too stupid. The developers choose to ignore their simple needs.

content: Actually the entire message pane is expanded to the length of the attachment filename. So if the message window is narrower than the filename, all elements of the message pane justified to the right (scroll bars, buttons, etc) are pushed off the window and not accessible. The window with the message pane must be widened until the filename is fully displayed.
creator: johned0420

content: Still haven't figured out why can't send email with Thunderbird and if I should override that warning message without understanding why it is displaying.
creator: seekinganswer

content:
I got this to start working for the email addresses that were showing that error message whenever I unsuccessfully tried to send an email from those addresses by doing this: I changed the smtp server settings from smtp.astound.net to mail.astound.net. That looks like it solved the problem.

However it is not clear to me why that previous setting worked for many months until recently. I still have the test emails for all of those addresses which were successfully sent in February when setting up those addresses. For at least one of those addresses I could still send successfully as recently as September. So I don't know if there was a change in Thunderbird or if it was some other reason that caused those addresses to not send. Maybe it would have sent if I overrode the warning message but I was hesitant to do that without understanding the reason it was displaying.

So all seems to be working again now. If anyone has any insight about the reasons why it wasn't working until making those changes today in the account settings for the smtp server that would be informative.
creator: seekinganswer

content:
You have chosen to communicate with the mail server in an encrypted mode. The certificate offered by the server when you connect is for a different server than the one you are attempting to connect to, so the computer is asking the human to make a decision as to if smtp.astound.net is the same as mail.astound.net. or if it is ok to use that certificate at all as the names are not matched.

I would guess you either previously allowed and exception that has changed, or the mail provider changed the name of the server you should use and the name on the certificate for that server. This is the most probable event. Fundamentally it has nothing to do with Thunderbird at all. Despite Thunderbird failing to get mail because you did not make a decision. The server names and the details on the certificates issued are all determined by the server operators, not Thunderbird.

creator: ialagon

content:
Para diagnosticar problemas en Thunderbird, prueba una de las siguientes soluciones:

  • Reinicia Thunderbird con los complementos desactivados (Thunderbird en Modo Seguro). En el menú de Ayuda, haz clic en "Reiniciar con los complementos desactivados...". Si Thunderbird funciona bien, hay algún complemento o tema que interfiere en el funcionamiento normal de Thunderbird. Tendrás que volver a activar todos los complementos hasta que localices dónde está el problema.
  • Reinicia el sistema operativo en Modo a prueba de fallos. De esta forma se cargará solo lo necesario para que pueda arrancar el ordenador y se activará la conexión a Internet. Para obtener instrucciones sobre cómo reiniciar tu sistema operativo en modo seguro, haz clic en él:

https://support.microsoft.com/es-es/windows/iniciar-el-pc-en-modo-seguro-en-windows-92c27cff-db89-8644-1ce4-b3e5e56fe234

Si reiniciando el sistema operativo en modo seguro se ha resuelto el problema, el que causa los problemas es algún otro software de tu equipo. Algunas de esos softwares pueden ser (aunque no son los únicos): AV scanning, virus/malware, descargas de fondo (por ejemplo, actualizaciones de programas), etc.
